title: Aliphatic extractive effects on acetic acid catalysis of typical agricultural residues to xylo-oligosaccharide and enzymatic hydrolyzability of cellulose
reasoning: The abstract compares benzene–ethanol extraction with single ethanol extraction and explicitly states that single ethanol extraction was safer, more environmentally friendly, and more cost-effective than benzene–ethanol solvent. This indicates ethanol extraction as a safer alternative to benzene-containing solvent.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to benzene. It only compares the effectiveness and safety of benzene–ethanol extraction versus ethanol extraction, mentioning that ethanol extraction is safer and more environmentally friendly, but does not specify particular harms of benzene.

title: Assessment of Harmful Emissions from Multiple Binder Systems in Pilot-Scale Sand Casting
reasoning: The abstract explicitly states that inorganic binders (sodium silicate and geopolymer) achieved reductions of over 90% in BTEX compounds, including benzene, compared to organic systems. It also highlights substantial decreases in other harmful emissions, supporting these inorganic binders as safer alternatives to conventional organic binders that emit benzene.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text discusses reductions in hazardous emissions including benzene but does not explicitly state any harms or hazards associated with benzene itself.

title: Properties of substitute motor fuels produced from ethanol in biorefineries
reasoning: The abstract presents EtG fuel (Ethanol to Gasoline) as a replacement fuel for motor gasoline with a limited content of benzene and sulfur, implying a safety advantage due to reduced benzene content. This suggests EtG is a safer alternative to conventional gasoline containing benzene.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to benzene. It only mentions that the EtG fuel has a limited content of benzene, without specifying any associated toxicity or hazard.
